SENT.plain: INTRODUCTION: Cerebral air embolism is a neurological emergency
It has been reported following cardiac catheterization, central venous catheter insertion, and cardiothoracic surgery
METHODS AND RESULTS: We report a case of massive cerebral air embolism secondary to intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) rupture
Computed tomography (CT) of the brain showed serpiginous hypodensities following the sulci associated with hypodense brain parenchymal lesions
CONCLUSION: The prompt recognition of cerebral air embolism secondary to IABP rupture requires a high level of suspicion and is confirmed by head CT
